title: French prisons' vulnerability in the face of drug trafficking
summary: The attack on a French prison van, in which two officers were killed on Tuesday, once again highlighted the difficulties faced by the prison administration in dealing with large-scale drug traffickers when they are incarcerated.

title: Nestled between Russia and North Korea, the hopes and frustrations of a piece of China
summary: Those living on a strip of land wedged between North Korea and Russia hope to benefit from Beijing's deepening relations with Moscow.

title: Cannes 2024: Judith Godrèche's film 'Moi Aussi' unveils a thousand faces of sexual violence victims
summary: The actress' short film was screened on Wednesday, May 15, opening the 'Un Certain Regard' section.

title: Azerbaijan's interference operations in New Caledonia is only part of the story
summary: On Thursday, the French government accused Baku of aggravating the situation on the island. While the country's role in certain past destabilization campaigns is undeniable, its involvement in the current tensions remains questionable.

title: Netherlands' new coalition led by the far right promises anti-migrant measures
summary: Geert Wilders, leader of the Party for Freedom, will not serve as prime minister, but will lead the coalition, which has adopted a government program.

title: Euro 2024: Didier Deschamps announces 25-man squad for summer tournament
summary: France coach Didier Deschamps included midfielder N'Golo Kanté, 33, in his preliminary list of players for the European Championship on Thursday and gave a first call-up to Paris Saint-Germain forward Bradley Barcola.

title: Slovak police charge man with attempted murder of PM Fico
summary: The alleged shooter was described as a 'lone wolf' who was unhappy with the results of the presidential elections.

title: Putin meets with Xi in China to test 'no-limits' friendship
summary: The Russian president is visiting China on May 16 and 17. He is due to travel to a technology institute under US sanctions.

title: Former French minister Damien Abad charged with rape
summary: The attempted rape charge dates from a 2010 incident at a party the former minister of solidarity gave at his Paris home. Two other cases dating from 2010 and 2011 are still being investigated.

title: Texas governor pardons man convicted of murdering Black Lives Matter protestor
summary: Republican Governor Greg Abbott issued a full pardon Thursday for a former US Army sergeant convicted of murder for fatally shooting an armed demonstrator in 2020 during nationwide protests against police violence and racial injustice.

title: New Caledonia: Gendarme killed by friendly fire during third night of unrest
summary: Five people have died during three nights of rioting, including two gendarmes. One was accidentally shot by another law enforcement officer.

title: Paris 2024: Wembanyama headlines France's preliminary basketball roster
summary: France head coach Vincent Collet announced an extended list of 19 players on Thursday featuring notable NBA stars Victor Wembanyama and Rudy Gobert. The roster will be trimmed to 12 players for the tournament.

title: Chad's junta leader officially declared winner of presidential election
summary: Chad's constitutional council confirmed Thursday that President Mahamat Déby Itno, who seized power in 2021, was elected president in the May 6 vote and rejected an appeal by his main opponent.

title: Mélenchon pursues search for African allies with Senegal trip
summary: The leader of France's radical left is on a four-day visit to Senegal, where he has met with the new prime minister, Ousmane Sonko.

title: US formally moves to reclassify marijuana as a less dangerous drug in historic shift
summary: 'This is monumental,' President Joe Biden said in a video statement on Thursday, calling the proposed rule an important move toward reversing longstanding inequities.

title: War in Ukraine: Washington no longer rules out its weapons being used to strike Russian soil
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken hinted on Wednesday that Ukrainian forces could bomb Russia with military materiel supplied by the US, something they had previously been forbidden from doing.

title: Why and how TikTok was banned in New Caledonia
summary: The French government blocked the social media app after a state of emergency was declared on the island. It is an unprecedented measure in the EU.

title: French prison van attackers are 'public enemy No 1,' says minister
summary: Speaking on French television, the interior minister vowed to do everything to bring to justice the gunmen who attacked a prison van and killed two prison officers on Tuesday.

title: New Caledonia sees fourth night of unrest, but France reports situation 'calmer'
summary: The French government office reported that a school and two businesses were set on fire Thursday night.

title: How digital nomadism became a market
summary: Short-term 'co-living' platforms offer luxury accommodation in exceptional locations such as South Africa, the Alps, Costa Rica, and many more to those who can choose where they work.

title: The myth of cancel culture in Swedish universities
summary: An investigation commissioned by the Swedish government shows that the phenomenon is minimal and does not pose a threat to academic freedom. Teachers and researchers believe political interference is a bigger concern.

title: Cannes 2024: 'L'Histoire de Souleymane,' when real life mirrors fiction
summary: In France for six years, the 23-year-old Guinean Abou Sangare, who gives a dazzling performance in Boris Lojkine's film, has just had his application for legalization rejected.

title: Protests against Gaza war take hold across European campuses
summary: Following their counterparts in the United States, students across Europe are occupying their establishments, demanding an end to Israeli bombardments in Gaza and that their universities divest from Israel.

title: 'There is no global conflict: Strategic rivalry coexists with economic cooperation'
summary: Exploiting the anger provoked by Israel's bombardment of Gaza, Moscow and Beijing have hoped to rally as many countries as possible to their cause. However, the thesis of a world structured around the rivalry between this duo and the West is reductive, writes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

title: Police kill man trying to set fire to synagogue in Rouen, France
summary: According to Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin, the man was armed and 'clearly' wanted to set fire to the religious building.

title: New Caledonia's economy is collapsing
summary: After a fourth night of unrest in the French overseas territory, nothing seems to be able to stop the destruction of the archipelago's economy. The government convened a crisis unit on Thursday to assess the situation.

title: Paris Olympics 2024: 500 recipes on the athletes' menu, but no burgers or fries
summary: The restaurant in the Athletes' Village, open 24/7 for the duration of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, will have to meet competitors' high standards, nutrition being key to sporting success.

title: Ukrainian soldiers in Donbas are fed up waiting for Western munitions
summary: Neither the shells included in the 'Czech plan' announced this winter, nor those tied to US aid approved at the end of April, have reached the front line, undermining the morale of Ukrainian troops.

title: Violence is now a feature of Europe's political landscape
summary: After the assassination attempt on Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico, Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk says he has received threats of violence.

title: EU elections: Raphaël Glucksmann, the opponent Macron's camp never saw coming
summary: The presidential camp's strategy of ignoring the left-wing candidate is crumbling as the June 9 elections loom and Glucksmann is closing in on candidate Valérie Hayer.

title: South Pacific countries are watching France and how it handles New Caledonia situation
summary: The region's island nations are paying close attention to the violent crisis shaking the French overseas territory, and are calling for a return to dialogue in the archipelago.

title: New Caledonia: Six questions to understand the current crisis
summary: Tensions in the French overseas territory exploded on May 13, leaving 5 people dead and dozens injured four days later. The government declared a state of emergency on May 15.

title: Slovak PM Fico's condition 'still very serious' after second surgery
summary: Robert Fico's condition was said to still be 'very serious' on Friday after it was reported he had a second operation following an attempted assassination.

title: Zelensky signs law to enable prisoners to join the army's ranks
summary: Another law will also increase fines for those who dodge the draft.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: Three major Paris roads closed to traffic from Friday
summary: The first road closures in Paris began on Friday, May 17, to allow for the construction of infrastructure for the Olympics.

title: Israel's army and Netanyahu are at odds over war in Gaza
summary: Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant has openly criticized the prime minister's refusal to establish a Palestinian political authority in Gaza, thus paving the way for the establishment of Israeli military rule.

title: Putin rejects Macron's call for Ukraine ceasefire during Olympics
summary: The French president restated on Friday his idea of 'an Olympic truce so that Russia ceases its current operations' in Ukraine, to Putin's disapproval.

title: Sweden boosts security after gunshots heard near Israeli embassy
summary: Swedish police have strengthened security measures around Israeli property, as well as the country's Jewish community interests, and also carried out searches in Stockholm.

title: Israel says it has recovered bodies of 3 hostages
summary: The military claimed the bodies of 3 hostages taken at the October 7 music festival, including the body of German-Israeli Shani Louk, were found overnight, without elaborating, and did not give immediate details on where they were located.

title: Paris by bike: Ten leafy pitstops from the Opéra to the Buttes-Chaumont park
summary: Black pines, paulownias, date palms and Japanese sophoras are just some of the remarkable trees featured in this bicycle tour of the capital's 9th to 19th arrondissements. These green pitstops are as educational as they are refreshing.

title: Man who attacked Nancy Pelosi’s husband with a hammer sentenced to 30 years
summary: Right-wing conspiracy theorist David DePape broke into Nancy Pelosi's home in October 2022 in the hopes of kidnapping the then-House Speaker.

title: France's La Poste celebrates baguette with bakery-scented stamp
summary: The French post office unveiled on Thursday, the day of the patron saint of bakers and pastry chefs, a scratch-and-sniff post stamp, which costs €1.96.
